text:
This video is brought to you by Curiosity
Stream.

Get 31 days of free documentaries on the link
down below.
Ryzen 3000 generation hype.
Zen 2 architecture for increased performance.
Navi architecture.
A return to the semblance of reasonable pricing in the pc gaming industry.
All for the low entry price of $200...
the price of an entire game console.
Ok so…
I am actually a fan of the Ryzen series.

Its introduction meant a comparatively cheaper
alternative to intel

that is forcing them to compete and at least
do something to deal with the rising cost
of enthusiast PC Gaming.

Most of them tended to be outside my range
of affordability but things changed when they
starting doing Ryzen APUs.

While AMD was off wooing people with the second
generation Ryzen 12 nm Zen+ architecture

they released a couple of more "affordable"
14 nm Zen APUs.

It's like trickle-down economics, only that
is new-gen tech making last-gen tech more

affordable and easier to produce and that
in here it actually works.

And these were APUs which means they came
with integrated graphics using VEGA, which
was at the time their best graphics architecture.

AMD had successfully managed to combine their
CPU and GPU expertise in something that redefined

a lot of what people thought of integrated
graphics.

While I was initially skeptical of these products
mainly due to them scratching the surface

of what I would consider entry-level in terms
of pricing I eventually warmed up to their
benefits and so did many people online,

as you can rarely look for a budget "console
killer" build guide online without seeing
one of these.

When they eventually manage to cut the same
tech down to a $55 budget I was very much

on board and this leap in integrated performance
definitely

caught intel's attention which now seems ready
to respond, something that I am very much
looking forward to testing.

So when the fabled 7 nm Zen 2 started showings
its head and all the mainstream tech channels
were busy talking about its bazillion cores

my eyes turned into the lower part of the
table where two new Zen + APUs sat waiting
in plain sight.

The cheapest of them was the Ryzen 3 3200G,
taking the place of the 2200G in terms of

pricing but with a number of improvements,
most notable on the CPU side and it is an

interesting example of how with every new
generation what we can get for the same price
changes in a positive way.

Same 4 cores but a jump from the first-generation
Zen architecture to the last generation Zen+
architecture, and some improvements on clocks.

So let's start testing with that before even
touching the topic of the GPU.

For CPU power testing most channels out there
use CSGO, but frankly, any game this light

and using an old engine is going to be CPU
bound if you use a ***** RTX 2080 and even

if I use it on a low resolution to tax the integrated
GPU as little as possible in a quick benchmark

map it is hard to tell what is improvements
from the CPU and what is from the GPU and

at this level of performance so this is 
not very interesting to me.
So let's try the latest Assassin's Creed games!

Either due to a quirk of DRM or just weird
CPU optimization both these games use way

too many CPU resources, which make them the
bane of entry-level CPUs.

If you drop the internal resolution to very
dramatic low levels and disable some effects

using the tricks on their respective videos
the CPU quickly becomes the main performance
limit.

Now on the old generation 2200G the CPU does
quite well, but it does stutter and freeze
while hitting 100% CPU usage on certain areas of Assassins Creed Origins.

On Odyssey, the newer game, is not as horrible
optimized and so does a fair bit better but

the results were a little bit dissapointing when you
consider than on the CPU front this guy was

able to do 60 fps on pretty much any other
game on lowest settings.

So, how does a jump to Zen+ benefited the
3200G?
Quite a lot actually.

Framerate on Origins is immediately not only
higher but more stable as stuttering is almost
completely gone.

And on the side Odyssey there is an obvious
jump in performance.

Seriously, this is more of a jump than I expected
it borders on a 60 FPS average which I have
seen older gaming CPUs struggling to maintain.
The jump to Zen+ was not a joke.

Now the surprise of the CPU improvements is
contrasted by the initial disappointment in
integrated GPU as this time we find... that it basically has the same integrated GPU as the older 2200G.

While I was secretly hoping for Navi the new
architecture in retrospective it is obvious

that such new technology might not be mature
enough to be put on a small package just yet.

So what we get is the same Vega 8 integrated
GPU at the slightly better clock.
Not even more Vega cores which is... weird.
This very modest change does not mean much.

For example, I ran a better-optimized game
Far Cry 5 on vanilla lowest settings and full

720p and the gains from Ryzen 2200G to 3200G
are modest.
Good, but like not earth-shattering or anything.

But this, my dear viewers, is not the full
story.

I was surprised when I noticed that even when
confronted with a GPU stress test the integrated
GPU temperature was not... very high.

My very uneducated guess is that improvements
in Zen+ or better thermal design freed some

of the thermal budgets which allowed that
increase in clocks and space for a bit more.

Now as I have proved in past videos I am no
overclocking expert and other people have

shown me that there are many variables outside
the CPU and its temperature that influence

what can be achieved, such as higher quality
power supplies that is able to keep a stable voltage

or better motherboards that filter that power
supply or have better cooling on the voltage
regulators

but even on a very overkill cooling and power
supply setup my old 2200 could only reach
1700 MHz on the GPU.

So imagine my surprise when using a suspiciously
cheap power supply an a ok motherboard with
nothing but the dinky stock cooler.

I could easily hit 1800 MHz right before hitting
what are probably unsafe voltages for this
component.

1800 MHz on the stock cooler with acceptable
temperatures!
That's crazy!

In fact, the only reason why I could not use
it was that upon opening any game the GPU
would start artifacting.

But a clock speed of 1700 MHz that required
all that freaking preparation on the 2200G

it was not a problem for the 3200G and the stock
cooler.

Results will vary because on every overclock
you will be depending on the silicon lottery but
this is still encouraging.

The combination of the ease of GPU overclock
and the improved Zen+ CPU leads to great results
such as Assassin's Creed Odyssey but this time on full 720 on at least 30 fps on nothing more than the
integrated GPU.

Considering the performance problems this
fantastic but heavy game can have, this is
rather good.

These GPUs are usually marketed at e-sports
titles, which is a code word for better optimized

competitive games which tends to have an e-sports
league built around them.
Not you, we will talk about you later.

And yeah big surprise, on the fantastically
optimized Overwatch it can do full 1080p at

nearly 60 FPS on this configuration without
a problem, only dropping in some really crazy
moments and even yet being pretty acceptable.
Let's throw some crazier stuff at it.
Like Wolfstein 2 the new colossus!

This is one of those titles that can trouble
to even dedicated GPUs and yet on this courtroom

combat scene the overclocked GPU is easily
able to keep 60 fps or more and this 720p

with no resolution scaling and shadows enabled,
which is usually the thing I recommend for

this game when struggling on your low end
PC.

Of all the games I tried this result is by
far the one that surprised me the most, as

I don’t think I had played this game with
shadows enabled on an integrated GPU ever
before.

So let's talk Nier: Automata, apart from being
just a really good game it is often a good

test of GPU power due to its computationally
expensive global illumination.

However, even with that illumination enabled
the overclocked Vega 8 had zero trouble with

the game at 720p which actually encouraged
me to

jump into 1080 where we had less luck... thankfully
I did a video on this game and on the FAR

mod that can disable that global illumination
for what is usually a substantial boost.

While the difference can be dramatic on older
GPUs here it slight but still important in
the long terms.

Not quite 60 FPS but still very surprising
performance for a game of this caliber.

And talking about 1080, before I single out
PUBG as the one exception among e-sporty games

that tend to be better optimized and historically
it has a harder time on integrated GPUs.

While updates through time have improved both
the optimization and qualities of things like

animations it is still surprising to see that
on the lowest settings this guy can fully

do 1080p with no resolution scaling on this
big game.
Another good sign!

So while on paper the changes between the
2200G and 3200G do not seem extremely dramatic,

in practice there is a bit of a hidden story
in here.

The jump to Zen + represents an improvement
in performance that is noticeable on those

extremely CPU heavy games and on the GPU department
we get basically the same Vega 8 with a small

clock boost but improvements on the thermals
somewhere make it easier to Overclock further

without changing the stock cooler which at
least in the case of my unit meant that I

could reach the limits of 1700 MHz with acceptable
temperatures and voltages, only limited by
actual artifacting of the GPU.

That improvement in thermals translates to
unexpectedly good performance, even on 1080

on some of the harder to run games using some
tricks.

Add to those improvements to the Ryzen Overclocking
software and motherboard bios, which make

it easy to set frequencies and voltages with
a quick test without a reboot and you can

see how the weird trickle-down of technology
is actually making

these Zen+ chips some of the most interesting
things to come out of the 3000 series, we

will see how the more expensive 3600G does
soon enough.

Although if you know me well you know that
I am more interested is in how this is going

to change the new generation of cheap Athlon
APUs, or how Intel's new GPU architecture
is going to compete.

But we will talk about those when the time
comes.

It is an interesting time to be an enthusiast
for the cheaper side of PC Gaming.

It is, in general, a decent time to be a nerd
with interesting indie and AAA games available

or coming and tons of cheap streaming services
for content
including Curiosity Stream.
You know how on Wolfstein you are fighting robot-nazis in like a moon base? A lot of it is inspired by some
of the frankly absurd experimental weapons World War II nazis tried, especially during the final stretch
of the war. It is a topic that is so weird that you can't help but be fascinated and you can learn lots about out it on
this fantastic documentary called Hitler's Miracle Weapons, which just one of the many high-quality pieces you can find there.

I was a bit late in finishing the script of this video
because I kinda got stuck watching this and

if historical weapons are not really your
thing you can find something among the

2400 documentary and non-fiction content of
Curiosity Stream a streaming service by the

founder of discovery channel available on
browser, phone, smart tv and all the usual

platforms for just 2.99 a month which is seriously
noting for the level of quality they offer.

And if you want to try for no money and support
the channel you can go to curiositystream.com/lowspecgamer
And get a 31 free trial...

Just be careful not to start a binge session...
which might be one the reasons why this
video is a couple of days later than I hoped.

Thank you to them for sponsoring this video,
and you for watching.
